{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3506134,"name":"Jesse L.","username":"scalenetwelve","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scalenetwelve/{size}/249580_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T19:41:15.720Z","cooked":"

Hello everyone,

I’m the programming mentor for FRC Team 9313, ROBOhana, a school-based team out of Inlet Beach, FL. This is our third year in FRC, though we’ve been competing in FTC for seven years. We’re a small team of eight students, so everyone takes on multiple roles.

Our team primarily uses Python because that’s the language I’m most familiar with, though I have no prior experience applying it to hardware. We used RobotPy last year with mecanum wheels, as we were accustomed to them from FTC—though we quickly learned how polarizing they can be in FRC!

This year, we’ve transitioned to swerve drive with the following setup:

• Drivetrain: 4x MK4i swerve modules

• Motors: 2x NEOs per module

• Encoders: Thriftybot absolute magnetic encoders (connected to RoboRIO analog ports)

• Gyro: NavX

We’ve been working on this for about 8 months, and while our drive base does move, it often does so inconsistently and in incorrect directions. We’ve been troubleshooting for a while but have hit a dead-end and aren’t sure what to try next. At this point, I’m looking for team-to-team mentorship rather than just troubleshooting a specific code issue. If there are teams out there who have successfully implemented swerve in Python (RobotPy) and are willing to mentor us, we’d be incredibly grateful for the guidance.

Our current code is available on GitHub: [ROBOhana Reefscape Repository] (GitHub - robohana/reefscape: Team 9313 ROBOhana 2025 reefscape code)

We’d love to connect via Discord, Zoom, or any preferred platform to talk through what we’re struggling with and get pointed in the right direction.

If you or your team are open to helping, please reply here or DM me. Any mentorship would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks in advance!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-08T19:41:15.720Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":34,"reads":173,"readers_count":172,"score":204.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485705,"topic_slug":"mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana","display_username":"Jesse L.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/robohana/reefscape","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - robohana/reefscape: Team 9313 ROBOhana 2025 reefscape code","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62081,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana/485705/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3506301,"name":"Andrew J (FRC 2881)","username":"mythgarr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mythgarr/{size}/238053_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-08T23:36:05.587Z","cooked":"

2881 has been running swerve for the past 2 seasons. We moved to python during the off-season and haven’t looked back - our students find it’s easier to follow than Java. Our base swerve drive code (absent any season-specific mechanisms) is at GitHub - frc2881/Robot-Base-Swerve: Source code for a base swerve drive robot

We’re using MAXSwerve modules with Vortex and SparkFlex - the main difference would be in the configuration of the turn motors. I’ve always used an absolute encoder connected to a SparkMax or the integrated absolute encoder in a SparkFlex - I’m afraid I can’t help much in providing feedback on that aspect of your design.

A few things stand out in the code as suspicious:

  • You are calling resetEncoders() from your drive() method. This is something we typically do at the start of a match or as part of a command.
  • SwerveModule.getState() adjusts for your rotation offset but I’m not seeing a corresponding adjustment in setDesiredState() - I could just be missing this. You can find an example of working implementation at Robot-Lib/components/swerve_module.py at 489b69b8513b7061912d13310a470507b09db56f · frc2881/Robot-Lib · GitHub

One thing that might help - if you publish your current and desired swerve states to NetworkTables you can connect to your robot with AdvantageScope to get a live view of what the robot is doing. AdvantageScope also record values so that you can pause, rewind and play back the robot’s view of things when things go wrong:

# In __init__()
networkTables = NetworkTableInstance.getDefault()
self._statePublish = networkTables.getStructArrayTopic("Sim/Drive/Modules/State", SwerveModuleState).publish()
self._desiredStatePublish = networkTables.getStructArrayTopic("Sim/Drive/Modules/DesiredState", SwerveModuleState).publish()

# In drive()
self._desiredStatePublish.set(swerveModuleStates)
self._statePublish.set(list([x.getState() for x in [self.frontLeft, self.frontRight, self.backLeft, self.backRight]]))

Feel free to reach out to me through DM to coordinate a meeting - Swerve is a fickle beast but it looks like you’re close.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-08T23:36:05.587Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":151,"readers_count":150,"score":35.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":485705,"topic_slug":"mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana","display_username":"Andrew J (FRC 2881)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/frc2881/Robot-Base-Swerve","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - frc2881/Robot-Base-Swerve: Source code for a base swerve drive robot","clicks":14},{"url":"https://github.com/frc2881/Robot-Lib/blob/489b69b8513b7061912d13310a470507b09db56f/components/swerve_module.py#L85","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Robot-Lib/components/swerve_module.py at 489b69b8513b7061912d13310a470507b09db56f · frc2881/Robot-Lib · GitHub","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":69490,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Andrew J"},"post_url":"/t/mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana/485705/2","custom_user_title":"Andrew J","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3521347,"name":"Andrew J (FRC 2881)","username":"mythgarr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mythgarr/{size}/238053_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-09T14:51:23.964Z","cooked":"

I spent some time this morning getting things running within a simulator. My first recommendation would be to use either 2881’s Swerve-Base or the MAXSwerve template published with robotpy as the basis for your code. You may have started from the latter but removed the use of Subsystem and RobotContainer and rewrote much of the DriveSubsystem and SwerveModule code.

If you’re set on fixing the code you’ve written thus far, I’ve found a few issues you’ll need to fix:

  • SlewRateLimiter stores state and cannot be reused for different inputs. Remove this from constants and instantiate new objects in your robotInit method.
  • Use a TrapezoidProfile rather than two SlewRateLimiters to limit X/Y acceleration. See the docs - “For input streams that control positions, it is usually better to use a proper trapezoidal profile.”
  • You should not be constructing rev.SparkBase objects - you should construct rev.SparkMax objects. The derived classes overload several methods which will not be called correctly otherwise.
  • Use network tables (ntcore.NetworkTableInstance) rather than print for debug information. This allows you to use AdvantageScope to record and playback the values with helpful visualization support for SwerveModuleState, SwerveModulePosition, Pose2d and other object types.
  • Use getLeftX() rather than getRawAxis(0) (ditto for other uses of getRawAxis). These abstractions exist for a reason - unless you’re using a non-standard HID device there’s likely no reason to interact with the raw data directly.

L.","username":"scalenetwelve","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/scalenetwelve/{size}/249580_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-09T19:31:50.027Z","cooked":"

Thank you so much for the detailed responses! This has already been a huge help.

I had no idea how powerful NetworkTables could be when combined with AdvantageScope—we had only used NT for our camera last year. Being able to visualize data like this is going to make debugging so much easier, and I really appreciate the recommendation!

As for the Command-based structure, we haven’t used it the past two years. It was something I wanted to implement, but with such a small team, I was hesitant about adding that complexity while also trying to get swerve working. That said, your explanation has convinced me that it’s necessary, so we’re making that transition now.

I’ll reach out through DM to coordinate a meeting if that’s okay—your help so far has already made a big difference, and I’d love to talk through some of these changes further.

Thanks again!

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-09T19:31:50.027Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":23.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485705,"topic_slug":"mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana","display_username":"Jesse L.","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":69490,"username":"mythgarr","name":"Andrew J (FRC 2881)","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mythgarr/{size}/238053_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62081,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana/485705/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3521613,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-09T21:31:56.150Z","cooked":"
scalenetwelve:

I was hesitant about adding that complexity while also trying to get swerve working.

Using a proper task scheduler should decrease - not increase - your code complexity. You are going to have to do the work the commands library would be doing somehow, because the problem space demands it.

I am the programmer for Team 9699, and we switched to python this year, as well as using swerve drive, and we are looking for a team that has more experience using both python and swerve drive, so please DM me so we can set up a meeting if possible.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-02-12T13:53:37.649Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":40,"readers_count":39,"score":8.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":485705,"topic_slug":"mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana","display_username":"Brayden Durocher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":73288,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Programmer"},"post_url":"/t/mentorship-for-programming-swerve-drive-with-robotpy-frc-team-9313-robohana/485705/6","custom_user_title":"Programmer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3527699,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-15T03:48:36.462Z","cooked":"

You should keep the slew rate limiting and other “control” stuff out of the drivetrain subsystem. Just leave the drivetrain only understanding things in units of velocity like meters/second. So you can think of your drive() method taking requests in the x/y values as being meters/second. And if the field relative flag is on the units stay the same.

For input scale this year we’re just deadbanding and then squaring, or taking it to a similar exponent. And the chassis knows max velocity so we keep our inputs between that. From there the chassis does the same thing to everything else before it drives: desatures and optimizes.

We’re using Magicbot ourselves instead of command based this year, but you might be able to glean something or another from our code. I’m linking to a branch that’s stable as we only update it if the drive practice team needs to try a new idea.

github.com

GitHub - TheTriSonics/Reefscape2025 at driver-practice

driver-practice

Robot code for Reefscape. Contribute to TheTriSonics/Reefscape2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.
